content: The Act may be cited as the "Deamonte Driver Dental Care Access Improvement Act of 2008". The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports an increase in tooth decay among toddlers and preschoolers. Young children are experiencing cavities, with 1-in-10 2-year-olds and 2-in-5 5-year-olds affected. Tooth decay is the most common childhood chronic disease, especially impacting poor and minority children. Parents are more likely to report unmet dental needs compared to general medical care needs. Children's dental needs are often unmet, with 23 million lacking dental insurance compared to 9 million without medical insurance. 40% of low-income adults have untreated decayed teeth, leading to 164 million work hours lost annually due to oral health issues. Additionally, 25% of adults aged 60 and older have no natural teeth. Having missing teeth can impact nutrition as individuals without natural teeth often prefer soft, easily chewed foods. SEC. 3. DENTAL WORKFORCE IMPROVEMENT. Dentistry Workforce Pilot Program introduced after section 747 of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary will provide grants to schools of dentistry and hospitals with accredited pediatric dentistry training programs to increase individuals in pediatric dentistry. Funds must be used to enhance academic programs, recruit and train dental students in pediatric dentistry, and strengthen training in pediatric dentistry within dentistry programs. The Secretary will provide grants to schools of dentistry and hospitals with accredited pediatric dentistry training programs to increase individuals in pediatric dentistry. Funds must be used for various purposes such as enhancing academic programs, recruiting and training dental students in pediatric dentistry, and strengthening training in pediatric dentistry within dentistry programs. Additionally, activities funded through grants will be evaluated biennially, and reports will be submitted to Congress. Authorization of appropriations is also provided for the implementation of these activities. Grants are authorized for fiscal years 2009 through 2014 to develop a pilot program training allied dental health professionals. Grants are authorized for a pilot program to train allied dental health professionals. The Secretary will award a grant to establish a pilot program to increase access to dental care for underserved populations through new allied dental health professionals. The program must evaluate different models, have professionals supervised by licensed dentists, include benchmarks for increasing access to care, and be replicable in other areas. The Secretary will adjust funding for the pilot program based on training needs and site usage. An evaluation will be conducted every two years, with appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2009 through 2014. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO DENTAL CARE. A pilot program for access to dental care is added to the Public Health Service Act. Funding will be adjusted based on training needs and site usage, with evaluations every two years. The Secretary will award grants to Federally qualified health centers to enhance dental services for medically underserved populations by recruiting dental professionals, acquiring equipment, expanding facilities, and facilitating partnerships with private providers. The Secretary will award grants to Federally qualified health centers to improve access to dental care for adults and children through mobile dentistry and teledentistry activities. Reports to Congress on the evaluation of funded activities are required biennially. Definitions include Federally qualified health center and pediatric dentist qualifications. The dentistry program is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2009 through 2014. "SEC. 330N. EARLY CHILDHOOD CARIES PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT DEMONSTRATION GRANTS." The Secretary can award grants to public or private entities to develop, implement, and evaluate strategies for preventing and managing early childhood caries. Funds can be used for developing detection methods, prevention materials, care delivery models, and training healthcare professionals in caries management. Practitioners can partner with early childhood programs to engage families in positive oral health behaviors and develop public health strategies targeting children under 6 years at risk for early childhood caries. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2009 through 2014. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2009 through 2014 for dental services credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Authorization of appropriations for dental services credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for fiscal years 2009 through 2014. The qualified dental services credit under section 38 allows for a 15% credit on qualified dental receipts, not exceeding $5,000 per taxpayer. Qualified dental receipts include compensation for dental services under specific state plans or from individuals without health insurance. The amendment to Section 38(b) adds a new paragraph (32) for the qualified dental services credit under section 45O(a). Additionally, the table of sections is updated to include this new item after section 45N. SEC. 330O. PUBLIC EDUCATION AND AWARENESS CAMPAIGN: The Secretary will conduct a public education campaign on preventing childhood caries, targeting pregnant women and caregivers of young children. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2009-2013. Access to dental care under Medicaid and SCHIP is addressed in Section 6. The text discusses amendments to reporting requirements for dental care for children under Medicaid and CHIP, including the inclusion of information on dental services provided to low-income children in annual reports. The text discusses amendments to reporting requirements for dental care for children under Medicaid and CHIP, including information on enrolled children by age grouping, preventive dental care for low-income children, and protective sealants for children aged 8. The Comptroller General of the United States will assess dental reimbursement rates for eligible beneficiaries under State Medicaid and child health plans, reporting to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The Act requires payment rates for services to be comparable to private health insurance, adequate to cover costs, and consistent with efficiency and quality of care under State Medicaid plans. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will coordinate with government agencies to include dental health in prenatal and child health programs. A report on the status of these programs must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
